Posts.Content: Mar 7, 2012 12:14PM IndigoMont11 wrote: Got the news on the MRI already!  Radiologist's office called me twice just now w/o leaving a message and I about passed out thinking they found something else.  But - yay, they didn't!  Cancer is only in the left side, right side only showed fibrocystic changes and the stable calcifications found several years ago - and best of all, lymph glands on both sides were clear.  But - always a "but" with this stuff, right? - the MRI says the "main" tumor is larger than what the US showed - 1.9 x 3 x 4.5 cm, and the entire area affected is about 9 cm.  They told me they wouldn't stage the cancer until after surgery, but this sure isn't looking like Stage 1. So... I'm glad I've kind of already been contemplating mastectomy because I'll be surprised if lumpectomy is really any kind of option given that info - even with the size of my girls. Gabsbaba, I sure hope your MRI goes as smoothly as mine.  I swear if it weren't for all of the space-age racket, I just about could have fallen asleep in there.  But I can ignore/shut out almost everything - just ask my sons, lol.

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2012 04:34PM - edited Mar 13, 2012 06:14PM by IndigoMont11 I'ml back. What a day! The surgeon was running late and then I think the sctual appt took over an hour. He was very scholarly; I was proud of myself that I understood all of his terminology. In a nutshell, as I thoughtsfter the MRiI report, the affected area is large enough, and the big tumor has lobular features, which would make getting clear margins harder, so lumpectomy not ag real option. I asked about chemo first to shrink the cancer but since it isn' t HER2 positive, the cancer would ptobably not respond as well, so I thought it sounded like postponing the inevitable. So that left it as a simple mastectomy. I had hoped for immediate recon but unfortunately that will have to wait. After I asked aboutthe chances of getting it on the other side and heard ten percent, it took me msybe a few hours to decide a one or two percent risk of recurrence sounded better. So I'm right behind you Gabsbaba, retiring the girls after 51 years. Hubby is freaking out. :( At least my boys are with me. I need a hug so bad right now.

I really don't know.  I had read it somewhere, I think, but had no real experience  (I was turning 14 at the time).  Anyway, that summer I went on a youth group trip (sailing on a schooner down the coast of Maine - so awesome!), and hung around with a bunch of kids who were cooler, hipper - and older - than I was.  I had a terrific crush on one of the boys.  Of course, totally one sided- he was just friendly to me, but we did have a lot of fun on my 14th birthday - I remember he filled my bunk with balloons, hung out with me all day and made it really special.  Anyway, I had befriended one of the other girls, who he also ended up paying "special" attention to - and when my period started in the middle of the trip (of course - why wouldn't it?), and I had awful cramps, I told her "I'm so horny!" Posts.Content: Apr 22, 2012 12:04AM IndigoMont11 wrote: Morning all, when I had my BMX in 3/2012, the anesthesiologist said instead of a regular tube that they used something smaller that from the sound of it didn't go into my throat nearly as far. As he said, I had no hoarseness or sore throat afterward. I didn't have immediate recon so my surgery took about 4 hours, I think, by comparison. It may be that with the longer procedures they might have to do a different intubation. Since you don't normally talk with the anesthesiologist until right before surgery, I recommend you find out if you can who it will be and ask them beforehand. Also - last little piece of advice- ask them for a nausea patch. They put one on me during prep and it worked like a charm; had no nausea whatsoever. They told me to keep it on for 3 days after surgery and I never had any problems.

Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2012 12:20PM IndigoMont11 wrote: OK, still kinda early in the game for me, but I finally got a little more info on rads.  My last chemo is September 13 (yay!!), and the RO's office said rads will start a month later.  No doubt a lot of you will have moved on by then!  I have been stressing a lot about my out of pocket cost (I am responsible for all of the copays which comes up to $1200 over 6 weeks), and have gotten the runaround a little bit as far as my options on possible assistance and payment plans, but yesterday I spoke with the MO's social worker and I feel a lot better about that now.  The sticky thing is, there is a good chance I could qualify for temporary assistance through Kaiser even just to pay the copays, but when I asked them about the application they told me that since I am having to be referred to a hospital for the actual radiation because the Kaiser facilities don't do it, their financial assistance won't pay for it either.  So most likely I'm looking at working out payments that I'll be able to afford, but I figured hospitals are probably used to that, and down the road, I'll be able to use my next year's flex to pay for it too (this year's flex is almost gone - didn't know last November I'd be dealing with f******* cancer, and I didn't plan to save enough!  I'm sure some of you know this already, but they also told me that w/o insurance the cost of rads is around $80,000. The RO's office didn't want to tell me much before I get referred to them, but they did tell me they do the tattoos, not sharpies.  That's okay with me; my bikini days were over a long time ago, and I'd rather not have to deal with getting drawn on multiple times or worrying about the ink staining my shirts.

Posts.Content: Nov 20, 2014 11:10PM IndigoMont11 wrote: I lost my eyebrows during Taxotere, too, and while they've grown back, they are very pale and very skimpy. No visible "tails" left at all. Hard to believe sometimes, because until I started tweezing as a teenager, I had really thick Brooke Shields of the '70s brows! I strongly recommend using a powder kit, like the Too Faced one mentioned by . My favorite is actually this kit from Glo Minerals: http://www.gloprofessional.com/product-type/makeup... I started using it during chemo and I love it. It comes with everything you need, and the flat angled brush is perfect for making "hair"-like strokes. Like some of the other kits, you get two colors that you can blend or use by themselves. I don't use the wax or the highlighter, though. I don't think the wax really works if you don't have hairs to start with, and the highlighter isn't really as good as shadows, anyway. The powders wear really well on me. The kit also comes with several stencils, but I usually draw my brows freehand. And the powders are paraben free.

Iago, were you a fit person before your surgery?  I'm not a smoker or drinker and my health looks like it's perfect except for the cancer, go figure.  However, after losing 30 pounds in 2004, I did what I *said* I would not do and gained 25 pounds back.  My big plan for this year was to work on improved fitness.  The bunion surgery derailed me a little bit but I'm back to taking good walks.  I just hope I'm fit enough to heal like you!  If the bunion surgery was any indication, the first week after that was the hardest too, and I ended up having to wait to take a full shower until the stitches were out in 2 weeks.  Ossa - I remember the 1980s band Chilliwack!  Are they still around at all? Doing it for you, not to you... I can remember that!!  I'm just trying to convince hubby.

Posts.Content: Feb 29, 2012 08:02AM IndigoMont11 wrote: I got a copy of my report from the 2/24 mammo and ultrasound.  It seems a bit more general than some I've seen here in the forum.... maybe Kaiser doesn't use the "BIRADS" or maybe this is just the way this radiologist wrote it up.  Anyway, it says: BILATERAL MAMMOGRAM, LEFT BREAST ULTRASOUND FINDINGS:  The breast tissue is heterogeneously dense.  This may lower the sensitivity of mammography.  A skin marker indicates a palpable lump in the left breast outer aspect [yep].  There is a corresponding focal assymetry.  Stable scattered calcifications in the right breast.  Targeted ultrasound of the palpable lump shows a 3.4 cm hypoechoic solid mass with irregular margins at 2:00, 9 cm from the nipple.  Additionally, there are multiple sub-5-mm masses present with one present at 3:00, 4 cm from the nipple.  Ultrasound of the axilla shows a lymph node with abnormal eccentric cortical thickening. [but yesterday, the radiologist disagreed and did not biopsy this.  Little whew.] IMPRESSION: Suspicious. This is more or less what they told me, except I didn't realize there were "multiple" smaller masses; they just mentioned one, and only biopsied the bigger one and one other area.  They did also tell me that based on prior history, they knew that I have had multiple cysts, so maybe that's what some of those masses are since they didn't specify that they were "solid." I'm taking another deep breath and trying to refocus on work....  At least, the biopsy sites hardly hurt at all today - didn't even take a tylenol this a.m.

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2012 12:02PM IndigoMont11 wrote: I have always felt like I wasn't brave enough because in my personal life, I hate conflict and it's always been hard for me to stand my ground when I've had to disagree with the people I love most - namely, DH, and sometimes, my oldest son.  We love each other like crazy but we're different personalities, and - well, anyway.  I told my mom about this feeling when I broke the news that I was getting tested and why, and God bless her, she wrote me a letter about all of the times she remembers me being brave.  I wanted to bring it with me and read it during a break but honestly, there's no way I'll be holding the tears back.  Dang it!  I guess being brave doesn't mean not crying or not being scared - it means doing what you have to do in spite of it.  At least, the fear I've had for most of my life of maybe getting this is one I think I can finally let go.  I actually have felt an incredible sense of freedom from that. This probably isn't making that much sense - thanks for "listening!!"

How long was it before you could sleep on your "bad" side?
